WATERCOLOR PAINT IS MADE OF GROUND PIGMENT mixed with a water soluble  _RL_ binding medium, usually gum arabic. It is usually applied to paper using soft  _RL_ hair brushes such as sable, goat hair, squirrel, and synthetic brushes.  _RL_ Watercolors are often diluted and applied as overlaying washes (thin,  _RL_ transparent layers) to build up depth of  color. Washes can be laid in a  _RL_ variety of  ways to create a range of  different effects. For example, a  _RL_ wet-in-wet wash can be achieved by laying a wash on top of  another wet  _RL_ wash. The two washes blend together to give a fused effect. Sponges are used  _RL_ to modify washes by soaking up paint so that areas of  pigment are lightened  _RL_ or removed from the paper. Watercolors can also be applied undiluted—a  _RL_ technique known as dry brush—to create a broken-color effect. Watercolors are  _RL_ generally transparent and allow light to reflect from the surface of  the paper through  _RL_ the layers of  paint to give a luminous effect. They can be thickened and made opaque  _RL_ by adding body color (Chinese white). _RL_

PASTELS ARE STICKS OF PIGMENT made by mixing ground pigment  _RL_ with chalk and a binding medium, such as gum arabic. They  _RL_ vary in hardness depending on the proportion of  the binding  _RL_ medium to the chalk. Soft pastel—the most common form  _RL_ of  pastel—contains just enough binding medium to hold the  _RL_ pigment in stick form. Pastels can be applied directly to  _RL_ any support (surface) with sufficient tooth (texture). When a  _RL_ pastel is drawn over a textured surface, the pigment crumbles  _RL_ and lodges in the fibers of  the support. Pastel marks have a  _RL_ particular soft, matte quality and are suitable for techniques  _RL_ such as blending, scumbling, and feathering. Blending is a  _RL_ technique of  rubbing and fusing two or more colors on the  _RL_ support using fingers or various tools such as tortillons  _RL_ (paper stumps), soft hair brushes, putty erasers, and soft  _RL_ bread. Scumbling is a technique of  building up layers of  _RL_ pastel colors. The side or blunted tip of  a soft pastel is  _RL_ lightly drawn over an underpainted area so that patches  _RL_ of  the color beneath show through. Feathering is a  _RL_ technique of  applying parallel strokes of  color with the  _RL_ point of  a pastel, usually over an existing layer of  _RL_ pastel color. A thin spray of  fixative can be applied—  _RL_ using a mouth diffuser (see pp. 430-431) or  _RL_ aerosol spray fixative—to a finished pastel  _RL_ painting, or in between layers of  color, to  _RL_ prevent smudging. _RL_

ACRYLIC PAINT IS MADE BY MIXING PIGMENT with a synthetic  _RL_ resin. It can be thinned with water but dries to become water  _RL_ insoluble. Acrylics are applied to many surfaces, such as  _RL_ paper and acrylic-primed board and canvas. A variety of  _RL_ brushes, painting knives, rollers, air-brushes, plastic  _RL_ scrapers, and other tools are used in acrylic painting.  _RL_ The versatility of  acrylics makes them suitable for a wide  _RL_ range of  techniques. They can be used opaquely or—by  _RL_ adding water—in a transparent, watercolor style. Acrylic  _RL_ mediums can be added to the paint to adjust its consistency  _RL_ for special effects such as glazing and impasto (ridges of  paint  _RL_ applied in thick strokes) or to make it more matt or glossy.  _RL_ Acrylics are quick-drying, which allows layers of  paint to   _RL_ be applied on top of  each other almost immediately. _RL_

CALLIGRAPHY IS BEAUTIFULLY FORMED LETTERING. The term applies  _RL_ to written text and illumination (the decoration of  manuscripts using  _RL_ gold leaf  and color). The essential materials needed to practice  _RL_ calligraphy are a writing tool, ink, and a writing surface. Quills  _RL_ are among the oldest writing tools. They are usually made from  _RL_ goose or turkey feathers, and are noted for their flexibility and  _RL_ ability to produce fine lines. A quill point, however, is not very  _RL_ durable and constant recutting and trimming is required.  _RL_ The most commonly used writing instrument in Western  _RL_ calligraphy is a detachable, metal nib held in a penholder.  _RL_ The metal nib is very durable, and there are a wide range  _RL_ of  different types. Particular types of  nibs—such as  _RL_ copperplate, speedball, and round-hand nibs—are used  _RL_ for specific styles of  lettering. Some nibs have integral ink  _RL_ reservoirs and others have reservoirs that are detachable.  _RL_ Brushes are also used for writing, and for filling in outlined  _RL_ letters and painting decoration. Other writing tools used in  _RL_ calligraphy are fountain pens, felt-tip pens, rotring pens,  _RL_ and reed pens. Calligraphy inks may come in liquid form,  _RL_ or as a solid ink stick. Ink sticks are ground down in  _RL_ distilled water to form a liquid ink. The most common  _RL_ writing surfaces for calligraphy are good quality, smooth  _RL_ -surfaced papers. To achieve the best writing position,  _RL_ the calligrapher places the paper on a drawing  _RL_ board set at an angle.  _RL_

PRINTS ARE MADE BY FOUR BASIC printing processes—intaglio,  _RL_ lithographic, relief, and screen. In intaglio printing, lines are  _RL_ engraved or etched into the surface of  a metal plate. Lines  _RL_ are engraved by hand using sharp metal tools. They are  _RL_ etched by corroding the metal plate with acid, using acid- _RL_ resistant ground to protect the areas not to be etched. The  _RL_ plate is then inked and wiped, leaving the grooves filled  _RL_ with ink and the surface clean. Dampened paper is laid   _RL_ over the plate, and both paper and plate are passed through  _RL_ the rollers of  an etching press. The pressure of  the rollers  _RL_ forces the paper into the grooves, so that it takes up the ink,  _RL_ leaving an impression on the paper. Lithographic printing is  _RL_ based on the antipathy between grease and water. An image  _RL_ is drawn on a surface—usually a stone or metal plate—with  _RL_ a greasy medium, such as tusche (lihographic ink). The  _RL_ greasy drawing is fixed on to the plate by applying an acidic  _RL_ solution, such as gum arabic. The surface is then dampened  _RL_ and rolled with ink. The ink adheres only to the greasy areas  _RL_ and is repelled by the water. Paper is laid on the plate and  _RL_ pressure is applied by means of  a press. In relief  printing, the  _RL_ nonprinting areas of  a wood or linoleum block are cut away  _RL_ using gouges, knives, and other tools. The printing areas are  _RL_ left raised in relief  and are rolled with ink. Paper is laid on  _RL_ the inked block and pressure is applied by means of  a press   _RL_ or by burnishing (rubbing) the back of  the paper. The   _RL_ most common forms of  relief  printing are woodcut, wood  _RL_ engraving, and linocut. In screen printing, the printing  _RL_ surface is a mesh stretched across a wooden   _RL_ frame. A stencil is applied to the mesh   _RL_ to seal the non printing areas and ink   _RL_
is scraped through the mesh to   _RL_ produce an image. _RL_

MOSAIC IS THE ART OF MAKING patterns and pictures from  _RL_ tesserae (small, colored pieces of  glass, marble, and other  _RL_ materials). Different materials are cut into tesserae using  _RL_ different tools. Smalti (glass enamel) and marble are cut  _RL_ into pieces using a hammer and a hardy (a pointed blade)  _RL_ embedded in a log. Vitreous glass is cut into pieces using  _RL_ a pair of  pliers. Mosaics can be made using a direct or  _RL_ indirect method. In the direct method, the tesserae are  _RL_ laid directly into a bed of  cement-based adhesive. In the  _RL_ indirect method, the design is drawn in reverse on  _RL_ paper or cloth. The tesserae are then stuck face-down  _RL_ on the paper or cloth using water-soluble glue. Adhesive  _RL_ is spread with a trowel on to a solid surface—such as  _RL_ a wall—and the back of  the mosaic is laid into the  _RL_ adhesive. Finally, the paper or cloth is soaked  _RL_ off to reveal the mosaic. Gaps between tesserae  _RL_ can be filled with grout. Grout is forced into  _RL_ gaps by dragging a grouting squeegee  _RL_ across the face of  the mosaic. Mosaics  _RL_ are usually used to decorate walls and  _RL_ floors, but they can also be applied  _RL_ to smaller objects. _RL_

THE TWO TRADITIONAL METHODS OF MAKING SCULPTURE are carving and modeling.  _RL_ A carved sculpture is made by cutting away the surplus from a block of  hard material  _RL_ such as stone, marble, or wood. The tools used for carving vary according to the  _RL_ material being carved. Heavy steel points, claws, and chisels that are struck with   _RL_ a lump hammer are generally used for stone and marble. Sharp gouges and chisels  _RL_ that are struck with a wooden mallet are used for wood. Sculptures formed from   _RL_ hard materials are generally finished by filing with rasps, rifflers, and other abrasive  _RL_ implements. Modeling is a process by which shapes are built up, using malleable  _RL_ materials such as clay, plaster, and wax. The material is cut with wire-ended tools  _RL_ and modeled with the fingers or a variety of  hardwood and metal implements. For  _RL_ large or intricate modeled sculptures an armature (frame), made from metal or  _RL_ wood, is used to provide internal support. Sculptures formed in soft materials   _RL_ may harden naturally or can be made more durable by firing in a kiln. Modeled  _RL_ sculptures are often first designed in wax or another material to be cast later in a  _RL_ metal (see pp. 454-455) such as bronze. The development of  many new materials in  _RL_ the 20th century has enabled sculptors to experiment with new techniques such as  _RL_ construction (joining preformed pieces of  material such as machine components,  _RL_ mirrors, and furniture) and kinetic (mobile) sculpture. _RL_

THE CIVILIZATION OF THE ANCIENT EGYPTIANS (which lasted  _RL_ from about 3100 bc until it was finally absorbed into the  _RL_ Roman Empire in 30 bc) is famous for its temples and  _RL_ tombs. Egyptian temples were often huge and  _RL_ geometric, like the Temple of  Amon-Re (below and  _RL_ right). They were usually decorated with hieroglyphs  _RL_ (sacred characters used for picture-writing) and painted  _RL_ reliefs depicting gods, Pharaohs (kings), and queens.  _RL_ Tombs were particularly important to the Egyptians,  _RL_ who believed that the dead were resurrected in the  _RL_ afterlife. The tombs were often decorated—as, for  _RL_ example, the surround of  the false door opposite—in  _RL_ order to give comfort to the dead. The best-known  _RL_ ancient Egyptian tombs are the pyramids, which  _RL_ were designed to symbolize the rays of  the Sun.  _RL_ Many of  the architectural forms used by the  _RL_ ancient Egyptians were later adopted by other  _RL_ civilizations; for example, columns and capitals  _RL_ were later used by the ancient Greeks (see pp.  _RL_ 460-461) and ancient Romans (see pp. 462-465). _RL_

THE CLASSICAL TEMPLES OF ANCIENT GREECE were built  _RL_ according to the belief  that certain forms and proportions  _RL_ were pleasing to the gods. There were three main ancient  _RL_ Greek architectural orders (styles), which can be  _RL_ distinguished by the decoration and proportions of  their  _RL_ columns, capitals (column tops), and entablatures  _RL_ (structures resting on the capitals). The oldest is the  _RL_ Doric order, which dates from the seventh century BC  _RL_ and was used mainly on the Greek mainland and in the  _RL_ western colonies, such as Sicily and southern Italy. The  _RL_ Temple of  Neptune, shown here, is a classic example of  _RL_ this order. It is hypaethral (roofless) and peripteral  _RL_ (surrounded by a single row of  columns). About a  _RL_ century later, the more decorative Ionic order developed  _RL_ on the Aegean Islands. Features of  this order include  _RL_ volutes (spiral scrolls) on capitals and acroteria  _RL_ (pediment ornaments). The Corinthian order was invented  _RL_ in Athens in the fifth century bc and is typically identified  _RL_ by an acanthus leaf  on the capitals. This order was later  _RL_ widely used in ancient Roman architecture.  _RL_

IN THE EARLY PERIOD OF THE ROMAN EMPIRE extensive use  _RL_ was made of  ancient Greek architectural ideas, particularly  _RL_ those of  the Corinthian order (see pp. 460-461). As a result,  _RL_ many early Roman buildings—such as the Temple of  Vesta  _RL_ (opposite)—closely resemble ancient Greek buildings. A  _RL_ distinctive Roman style began to evolve in the first century  _RL_ AD. This style developed the interiors of buildings (the Greeks  _RL_ had concentrated on the exterior) by using arches, vaults, and  _RL_ domes inside the buildings, and by ornamenting internal walls.  _RL_ Many of  these features can be seen in the Pantheon. Exterior  _RL_ columns were often used for decorative, rather than structural,  _RL_ purposes, as in the Colosseum and the Porta Nigra (see  _RL_ pp. 464-465). Smaller buildings had timber frames with  _RL_ wattle-and-daub walls, as in the mill (see pp. 464-465).  _RL_ Roman architecture remained influential for many centuries,  _RL_ with some of  its principles being used in the 11th century in  _RL_ Romanesque buildings (see pp. 468-469) and also in the 15th  _RL_ and 16th centuries in Renaissance buildings (see pp. 474-477). _RL_

WARFARE WAS COMMON IN EUROPE in the Middle  _RL_ Ages, and many monarchs and nobles built   _RL_ castles as a form of  defense. Typical medieval   _RL_ castles have outer walls surrounding a moat. Inside  _RL_ the moat is a bailey (courtyard), protected by a  _RL_ chemise (jacket wall). The innermost and strongest  _RL_ part of  a medieval castle is the keep. There are two  _RL_ main types of  keep: towers called donjons, such  _RL_ as the Tour de César and Coucy-le-Château,  _RL_ and rectangular keeps (“hall-keeps”), such as the  _RL_ Tower of  London. Castles were often guarded by  _RL_ salients (projecting fortifications), like those of  the  _RL_ Bastille. Medieval houses typically had timber cruck  _RL_ (tentlike) frames, wattle-and-daub walls, and pitched  _RL_ roofs, like those on medieval  _RL_ London Bridge (opposite). _RL_

DURING THE MIDDLE AGES, large numbers of  churches  _RL_ were built in Europe. European churches of  this period  _RL_ typically have high vaults supported by massive piers  _RL_ and columns. In the 10th century, the Romanesque  _RL_ style developed. Romanesque architects adopted  _RL_ many Roman or early Christian architectural   _RL_ ideas, such as cross-shaped ground-plans—like   _RL_ that of  Angoulême Cathedral (opposite)—and   _RL_ the basilican system of  a nave with a central  _RL_ vessel and side aisles. In the mid-12th century,  _RL_ flying buttresses and pointed vaults appeared.  _RL_ These features later became widely used in  _RL_ Gothic architecture (see pp. 470-471). Bagneux  _RL_ Church (opposite) has both styles: a Romanesque  _RL_ tower, and a Gothic nave and choir. _RL_

GOTHIC BUILDINGS are characterized  _RL_ by rib vaults, pointed or lancet arches,  _RL_ flying buttresses, decorative tracery  _RL_ and gables, and stained-glass windows.  _RL_ Typical Gothic buildings include the  _RL_ Cathedrals of  Salisbury and old  _RL_ St. Paul’s in England, and Notre  _RL_ Dame de Paris in France (see pp.  _RL_ 472-473). The Gothic style developed  _RL_ out of  Romanesque architecture in  _RL_ France (see pp. 468-469) in the mid-  _RL_ 12th century, and then spread throughout Europe. The  _RL_ decorative elements of  Gothic architecture became highly  _RL_ developed in buildings of  the English Decorated style (late  _RL_ 13th-14th century) and the French Flamboyant style  _RL_ (15th-16th century). These styles are exemplified by the  _RL_ tower of  Salisbury Cathedral and the staircase in the  _RL_ Church of  St. Maclou (see pp. 472-473), respectively. In  _RL_ both of  these styles, embellishments such as ballflowers  _RL_ and curvilinear (flowing) tracery were used liberally. The  _RL_ English Perpendicular style (late 14th-15th century),  _RL_ Nave _RL_ which followed the Decorated style, emphasized the  _RL_ vertical and horizontal elements of  a building. A notable  _RL_ feature of  this style is the hammer-beam roof. _RL_

THE RENAISSANCE was a European movement—lasting roughly  _RL_ from the 14th century to the mid-17th century—in which the arts   _RL_ and sciences underwent great changes. In architecture, these changes  _RL_ were marked by a return to the classical forms and proportions of  _RL_ ancient Roman buildings. The Renaissance originated in Italy, and   _RL_ the buildings most characteristic of  its style can be found there, such  _RL_ as the Palazzo Strozzi shown here. Mannerism is a branch of  the  _RL_ Renaissance style that distorts the classical forms; an example is  _RL_ the Laurentian Library staircase. As the Renaissance style spread   _RL_ to other European countries, many of  its features were incorporated  _RL_ into the local architecture; for example, the Château de Montal in  _RL_ France (see pp. 476-477) incorporates aedicules (tabernacles). _RL_

THE BAROQUE STYLE EVOLVED IN THE EARLY 17TH CENTURY in Rome. It is characterized  _RL_ by curved outlines and ostentatious decoration, as can be seen in the Italian church  _RL_ details (right). The baroque style was particularly widely favored in Italy, Spain,  _RL_ and Germany. It was also adopted in Britain and France, but with adaptations. The  _RL_ British architects Sir Christopher Wren and Nicholas Hawksmoor, for example,  _RL_ used baroque features—such as the concave walls of  St. Paul’s Cathedral and the  _RL_ curved buttresses of  the Church of  St. George in the East (see pp. 480-481)—but  _RL_ they did so with restraint. Similarly, the curved buttresses and volutes of  the  _RL_ Parisian Church of St. Paul-St. Louis are relatively plain. In the second half of   _RL_ the 17th century, a distinct classical style (known as neoclassicism) developed in  _RL_ northern Europe as a reaction to the excesses of  baroque. Typical of  this new style  _RL_ were churches such as the Madeleine (a proposed facade is shown below), as well  _RL_ as secular buildings such as the Cirque Napoleon (opposite) and the buildings of  _RL_ the British architect Sir John Soane (see pp. 482-483). In early 18th-century  _RL_ France, an extremely lavish form of  baroque developed, known as rococo.  _RL_ The balcony from Nantes (see pp. 482-483) with its twisted ironwork  _RL_ and head-shaped corbels is typical of  this style. _RL_

ARCHES ARE CURVED STRUCTURES used to bridge spans  _RL_ and to support the weight of  upper parts of  buildings,  _RL_ such as domes, as in St. Paul’s Cathedral (below) and  _RL_ the antique temple (opposite). The voussoirs (wedge- _RL_ shaped blocks) that form an arch (right) support  _RL_ each other and convert the downward force of  the  _RL_ weight of  the building into an outward force. This  _RL_ outward force is in turn transferred to buttresses, piers,  _RL_ or abutments. A vault is an arched roof  or ceiling. There are four  _RL_ main types of  vault (opposite). A barrel vault is a single vault, semicircular  _RL_ in cross-section; a groin vault consists of  two barrel vaults intersecting at  _RL_ right-angles; a rib vault is a groin vault reinforced by ribs; and a fan  _RL_ vault is a rib vault in which the ribs radiate from the springing  _RL_ point (where the arch begins) like a fan. _RL_

A DOME IS A CONVEX ROOF. Domes are categorized according  _RL_ to the shapes of  both the base and the section through the  _RL_ center of  the dome. The base may be circular, square, or  _RL_ polygonal (many-sided), depending on the plan of the drum  _RL_ (the walls on which the dome rests). The section of  a dome  _RL_ may be the same shape as any arch (see pp. 484-485).  _RL_ Various types of  dome are illustrated here: a  _RL_ hemispherical dome, which has a circular base  _RL_ and a semicircular section; a saucer dome,  _RL_ which has a circular base and a segmental  _RL_
(less than a semicircle) section; a polyhedral  _RL_

dome, which is a dome on a  _RL_ polygonal base whose sides meet  _RL_ at the top of  the dome; and   _RL_ an onion dome, which has  _RL_ a circular or polygonal base  _RL_ and an ogee-shaped  _RL_ section. Many domes have  _RL_

THE ISLAMIC RELIGION was founded by  _RL_ the prophet Mohammed, who was born in  _RL_ Mecca (in present-day Saudi Arabia) about  _RL_ 570 ad. In the following three centuries,  _RL_ Islam spread from Arabia to North Africa  _RL_ and Spain, as well as to India and much  _RL_ of  the rest of  Asia. The worldwide  _RL_

OPUS SECTILE  _RL_ MOSAIC DESIGN _RL_ influence of  Islam remains strong today.  _RL_ Common characteristics of  Islamic buildings  _RL_ include ogee arches and roofs, onion domes, and  _RL_ walls decorated with carved stone, paintings, inlays,  _RL_ or mosaics. The most important type of  Islamic  _RL_ building is the mosque—the place of  worship— _RL_ which generally has a minaret (tower) from  _RL_ which the muezzin (official crier) calls  _RL_ Muslims to prayer. Most mosques have a mihrab  _RL_ (decorative niche) that indicates the direction  _RL_ of Mecca. As figurative art is not allowed  _RL_ in Islam, buildings are ornamented with  _RL_ geometric and arabesque motifs, and  _RL_ inscriptions (frequently Koranic verses). _RL_

THE TRADITIONAL ARCHITECTURE of  south and east Asia has been  _RL_ profoundly influenced by the spread from India of  Buddhism and Hinduism.  _RL_ This influence is shown both by the abundance and by the architectural  _RL_ styles of  temples and shrines in the region. Many early Hindu temples  _RL_ consist of  rooms carved from solid rock-faces. However, free-standing  _RL_ structures began to be built in southern India from about the eighth  _RL_ century AD. Many were built in the Dravidian style, like the Temple of  _RL_ Virupaksha (opposite) with its characteristic antarala (terraced tower),  _RL_ perforated windows, and numerous arches, pilasters, and carvings.  _RL_ The earliest Buddhist religious monuments were Indian stupas,  _RL_ which consisted of  a single hemispherical dome surmounted by a  _RL_ chattravali (shaft) and surrounded by railings with ornate gates.  _RL_ Later Indian stupas and those built elsewhere were sometimes  _RL_ modified; for example, in Sri Lanka, the dome became bell-shaped,  _RL_ and was called a dagoba. Buddhist pagodas, such as the Burmese  _RL_ example (right), are multistoried temples, each story having a  _RL_ projecting roof. The form of  these buildings probably derived from  _RL_ the yasti (pointed spire) of  the stupa. Another feature of  many  _RL_ traditional Asian buildings is their imaginative roof-forms, such  _RL_ as gambrel (mansard) roofs, and roofs with angle-rafters (below). _RL_

BUILDINGS OF THE 19TH CENTURY are characterized by  _RL_ the use of  new materials and by a great diversity of  _RL_ architectural styles. From the end of  the 18th century,  _RL_ iron and steel became widely used as alternatives to  _RL_ wood for the framework of  buildings, as in the flax- _RL_ spinning mill shown here. Built in Britain in 1796,  _RL_ this mill exemplifies an architectural style that became  _RL_ common throughout the industrialized world for more  _RL_ than a century. The Industrial Revolution also brought  _RL_ mass-production of  building parts—a development  _RL_ that enabled the British architect Sir Joseph Paxton  _RL_ to erect London’s Crystal Palace (a building made  _RL_ entirely of  iron and glass) in only nine months, ready  _RL_ for the Great Exhibition of  1851. The 19th century  _RL_ saw a widespread revival of  older architectural  _RL_ styles. For example, in the US and Germany,  _RL_ Neo-Greek architecture was fashionable;  _RL_ in Britain and France, Neo-Baroque,  _RL_ Neo-Byzantine, and Neo-Gothic  _RL_ styles (as seen in the Palace of  _RL_ Westminster and Tower  _RL_ Bridge) were dominant. _RL_

ARCHITECTURE OF THE EARLY 20TH CENTURY is notable for radical new types of  _RL_ steel-and-glass buildings—particularly skyscrapers—and the widespread use of  _RL_ steel-reinforced concrete. The steel-framed skyscraper was pioneered in Chicago  _RL_ in the 1880s, but did not become widespread until the first decades of  the 20th  _RL_ century. As construction techniques were refined, skyscrapers became higher  _RL_ and higher; for example, the Empire State Building (right) of  1929-1931  _RL_ has 102 storeys. Many buildings of  this period were constructed from  _RL_ lightweight concrete slabs, which could be supported by cantilever  _RL_ beams or by pilotis (stilts), as in the Villa Savoye (below). The  _RL_ early 20th century also produced a great variety of  architectural  _RL_ styles, some of  which are illustrated opposite. Despite their  _RL_ diversity, the styles of  this period generally had one thing in  _RL_ common: they were completely new, with few links to past  _RL_ architectural styles. This originality is in marked contrast to 19th- _RL_ century architecture (see pp. 492-493), much of  which was revivalist. _RL_

ARCHITECTURE SINCE ABOUT THE 1950s is generally known  _RL_ as modern architecture. One of  its main influences has  _RL_ been functionalism—a belief  that a building’s function  _RL_ should be apparent in its design. Both the Centre Georges  _RL_ Pompidou (below and opposite) and the Hong Kong and  _RL_ Shanghai Bank (see pp. 498-499) are functionalist buildings:  _RL_ on each, elements of  engineering and the building’s services  _RL_ are clearly visible on the outside. In the 1980s, some architects  _RL_ rejected functionalism in favor of  post-modernism, in  _RL_ which historical styles—particularly neoclassicism—were  _RL_ revived, using modern building materials and techniques.  _RL_ In many modern buildings, walls are made of  glass or  _RL_ concrete hung from a frame, as in the Kawana House (right);  _RL_ this type of  wall construction is known as curtain walling.  _RL_ Other modern construction techniques include the intricate  _RL_ interlocking of  concrete vaults—as in the Sydney Opera House  _RL_ (see pp. 498-499)—and the use of  high-tension beams to  _RL_ create complex roof  shapes, such as the paraboloid roof  of  _RL_ the Church of  St. Pierre de Libreville (see pp. 498-499). _RL_

MUSICAL NOTATION IS ANY METHOD by which sounds are  _RL_ written down so that they can be read and performed by  _RL_ others. The present-day conventional system of  notation  _RL_ uses a five-line stave (staff)—divided by vertical lines into  _RL_ sections known as bars—on which notes, rests, clefs, key  _RL_ signatures, time signatures, accidentals, and other symbols  _RL_ are written. A note indicates the duration of  a sound and,  _RL_ according to its position on the stave, its pitch. Notes  _RL_ can be arranged on the stave in order of  pitch to  _RL_ form a scale. A silence in the music is indicated by  _RL_ a rest. The clef, which is placed at the begininng  _RL_ of  a stave, fixes the pitch. The key signature,   _RL_ which is placed after the clef, indicates the key.  _RL_ The time signature, placed after the key  _RL_ signature, shows the number of  beats in a bar.  _RL_ Accidentals are used to indicate the raising  _RL_ or lowering of  the pitch of  a note. _RL_

AN ORCHESTRA IS A GROUP of  musicians that  _RL_ plays music written for a specific combination of  _RL_ instruments. The number and type of  instruments  _RL_ included in the orchestra depends on the style of  _RL_ music being played. The modern orchestra (also  _RL_ known as a symphony orchestra) is made up  _RL_ of  four sections of  instruments—stringed,  _RL_ woodwind, brass, and percussion. The  _RL_ stringed section consists of  violins, violas,  _RL_ cellos (violoncellos), double basses, and  _RL_ sometimes a harp (see pp. 510-511). The main  _RL_ instruments of  the woodwind section are flutes,  _RL_ oboes, clarinets, and bassoons—the piccolo, cor  _RL_ anglais, bass clarinet, saxophone, and double  _RL_ bassoon (contrabassoon) can also be included  _RL_ if  the music requires them (see pp. 508-509).  _RL_ The brass section usually consists of  horns,  _RL_ trumpets, trombones, and the tuba (see  _RL_ pp. 506-507). The main instruments of  _RL_ the percussion section are the timpani  _RL_ (see pp. 518-519). The side drum,  _RL_ bass drum, cymbals, tambourine,  _RL_ triangle, tubular bells, xylophone,  _RL_ vibraphone, tam-tam (gong),  _RL_ castanets, and maracas can  _RL_ also be included in the  _RL_ percussion section (see  _RL_ pp. 516-517). The musicians  _RL_ are usually arranged in a semi- _RL_ circle—strings spread along the  _RL_ front, woodwind and brass in the  _RL_ center, and percussion at the back.  _RL_ A conductor stands in front of  the  _RL_ musicians and controls the tempo  _RL_ (speed) of  the music and the   _RL_ overall balance of  the sound,  _RL_ ensuring that no instruments  _RL_ are too loud or too soft in  _RL_ relation to the others. _RL_

BRASS INSTRUMENTS ARE WIND INSTRUMENTS that are made  _RL_ of  metal, usually brass. Although they appear in many  _RL_ different shapes and sizes, all brass instruments have a  _RL_ mouthpiece, a length of  hollow tube, and a flared bell.  _RL_ The mouthpiece of  a brass instrument may be cup- _RL_ shaped, as in the cornet, or cone-shaped, as in the  _RL_
horn. The tube may be wide or narrow, mainly  _RL_

conical, as in the horn and tuba, or mainly cylindrical, as in  _RL_ the trumpet and trombone. The sound of  a brass instrument  _RL_ is made by the player’s lips vibrating against the mouthpiece,  _RL_ so that the air vibrates in the tube. By changing lip tension,  _RL_ the player can vary the vibrations and produce notes of  _RL_ different pitches. The range of  notes produced by a brass  _RL_ instrument can be extended by means of  a valve system.  _RL_ Most brass instruments, such as the trumpet, have piston  _RL_ valves that divert the air in the instrument along an extra  _RL_ piece of  tubing (known as a valve slide) when pressed down.  _RL_ The total length of  the tube is increased and the pitch of  the  _RL_ note produced is lowered. Instead of  valves, the trombone  _RL_ has a movable slide that can be pushed away from or drawn  _RL_ toward the player. The sound of  a brass instrument can also  _RL_ be changed by inserting a mute into the bell of  the instrument. _RL_

WOODWIND INSTRUMENTS ARE wind instruments  _RL_ that are generally made of  wood, although some  _RL_ are made of  metal or plastic. The sound of  a  _RL_ woodwind instrument is produced by the  _RL_ vibration of  air in a hollow tube. The air  _RL_ is made to vibrate by blowing across a  _RL_ blow hole—as in the flute and piccolo— _RL_ or by blowing through a single reed— _RL_ as in the clarinet and saxophone— _RL_ or a double reed—as in the  _RL_ bassoon, cor anglais, and  _RL_ oboe. The pitch of  a  _RL_ woodwind instrument  _RL_ can be changed by  _RL_ opening or closing  _RL_ holes cut into   _RL_ the tube of   _RL_ the instrument. _RL_

STRINGED INSTRUMENTS PRODUCE SOUND by the vibration  _RL_ of  stretched strings. This may be done by drawing a bow  _RL_ across the strings, as in the violin; or by plucking the strings,  _RL_ as in the harp and guitar (see pp. 512-513). The four modern  _RL_ members of  the bowed string family are the violin, viola, cello  _RL_ (violoncello), and double bass. Each consists of  a hollow,  _RL_ wooden body, a long neck, and four strings. The bow is a  _RL_ wooden stick with horsehair stretched across its length.  _RL_ The vibrations made by drawing the bow across the strings  _RL_ are transmitted to the hollow body, and this itself  vibrates,  _RL_ amplifying and enriching the sound produced. The harp  _RL_ consists of  a set of  strings of  different lengths stretched  _RL_ across a wooden frame. The strings are plucked  _RL_ by the player’s thumbs and fingers—except  _RL_ the little finger of  each hand—which  _RL_ produces vibrations that are amplified  _RL_ by the harp’s sound board. The pitch  _RL_ of  the note produced by any stringed  _RL_ instrument depends on the length,  _RL_ weight, and tension of  the string.  _RL_ A shorter, lighter, or tighter string  _RL_ gives a higher note. _RL_

THE GUITAR IS A PLUCKED stringed instrument  _RL_ (see pp. 510-511). There are two types of  guitar— _RL_ acoustic and electric. Acoustic guitars have hollow  _RL_ bodies and six or 12 strings. Plucking the strings  _RL_ produces vibrations that are amplified by their hollow  _RL_ bodies. Electric guitars usually have solid bodies and  _RL_ six strings. Pick-ups placed under the strings convert  _RL_ their vibrations into electronic signals that are magnified  _RL_ by an amplifier, and sent to a loudspeaker where they are  _RL_ converted into sounds (see pp. 520-521). Electric bass  _RL_ guitars are very similar in structure to electric guitars,  _RL_ and produce sound in the same way, but have four  _RL_ strings and play bass notes. _RL_

KEYBOARD INSTRUMENTS are instruments  _RL_ that are sounded by means of  a keyboard.  _RL_ The organ and piano are two of  the  _RL_ principal members of  the keyboard  _RL_ family. The organ consists of  pipes that  _RL_ are operated by one or more manuals  _RL_ (keyboards) and a pedal board. The  _RL_ pipes are lined up in rows (known as  _RL_ ranks or registers) on top of  a wind  _RL_ chest. The sound of the organ is made  _RL_ when air is admitted into a pipe by  _RL_ pressing a key or pedal. The piano  _RL_ consists of wire strings stretched over  _RL_ a metal frame, and a keyboard and pedals that  _RL_ operate hammers and dampers. The piano frame  _RL_ is either vertical—as in the upright piano—or  _RL_ horizontal—as in the grand piano. When a key is  _RL_ at rest, a damper lies against the string to stop it from  _RL_ vibrating. When a key is pressed down, the damper  _RL_ moves away from the string as the hammer strikes  _RL_ it, causing the string to vibrate and sound a note. _RL_

PERCUSSION INSTRUMENTS are a large group  _RL_ of  instruments that produce sound by being  _RL_ struck, shaken, scraped, or clashed together.  _RL_ Most percussion instruments—such as the  _RL_ tam-tam (gong), cymbals, and maracas—do  _RL_ not have a definite pitch and are used for  _RL_ rhythm and impact, and the distinctive  _RL_ timber (color) of  their sound. Other percussion instruments— _RL_ such as the xylophone, vibraphone, and tubular bells—are tuned  _RL_ to a definite pitch and can play melody, harmony, and rhythms.  _RL_ The xylophone and vibraphone each have two rows of  bars that  _RL_ are arranged in a similar way to the black and white keys of  a  _RL_ piano. Metal tubes are suspended below the bars to amplify the  _RL_ sound. The vibraphone has electrically operated fans that rotate  _RL_ in the tubes and produce a vibrato (wavering pitch) effect. _RL_

A DRUM IS A percussion instrument that  _RL_ consists of  a drumhead, made of  skin or  _RL_ plastic, stretched over one or both ends of  _RL_ a hollow vessel (the body shell). Drums  _RL_ are played in most parts of  the world and  _RL_ are made in a number of  different shapes  _RL_ and sizes. They can be divided into three  _RL_ groups according to the shape of  the  _RL_ TAMBOURINE _RL_ body-shell: frame drums (e.g., tambourines), bowl- _RL_ shaped drums (e.g., timpani), and tubular drums  _RL_ (e.g., congas). Drums are usually sounded by  _RL_ striking the drumhead with the hands or with  _RL_ beaters, such as a hard-headed stick. The  _RL_ drumhead vibrates, and its vibrations  _RL_ are amplified by the hollow body shell.  _RL_ The snare drum has wires—known  _RL_ as snares—stretched across the lower  _RL_ drumhead; the snares vibrate against  _RL_ the lower drumhead when the drum is  _RL_ played. Most drums, such as congas,  _RL_ do not have a definite pitch and can play  _RL_ only rhythms (see pp. 516-517). Other drums,  _RL_ such as timpani, have a definite pitch and can  _RL_ play melody, harmony, and rhythms. They can be  _RL_ tuned by adjusting the tension of  the drumhead.  _RL_ Different types of  drum can be combined together  _RL_ with other percussion instruments to form a drum  _RL_ set. The basic components of  the drum set are  _RL_ bass drum, tom-toms, floor tom (tenor drum),  _RL_ snare drum, and cymbals. _RL_

ELECTRONIC INSTRUMENTS generate electronic signals  _RL_ that are magnified by an amplifier and sent to a loudspeaker,  _RL_ where they are converted into sounds. Synthesizers, and other  _RL_ electronic instruments, simulate the characteristic sounds of  _RL_ conventional instruments, and also create entirely new sounds.  _RL_ Most electronic instruments are keyboard instruments, but electronic  _RL_ wind and percussion instruments are also popular. A digital sampler  _RL_ records and stores sounds from musical instruments or other sources.  _RL_ When the sound is played back, the pitch of  the original sound can be  _RL_ altered. A keyboard can be connected to the sampler so that a tune can  _RL_ be played using the sampled sounds. With a MIDI (Musical Instrument  _RL_ Digital Interface) system, a computer can be linked with other electronic  _RL_ instruments, such as keyboards and electronic drums, to make sounds  _RL_ together or in sequence. It is also possible, using music software, to  _RL_ compose and play music on a home computer. _RL_

GAMES INVOLVING KICKING A BALL have a long history and were  _RL_ recorded in China as early as 300 BC; in medieval Europe, street  _RL_ football was banned as a menace to the public; only in 1863 were  _RL_ the rules established, specifically banning carrying the ball for all  _RL_ players except the goalkeeper, and separating rugby from soccer.  _RL_ Soccer, officially termed association football, is a team sport in  _RL_ which players attempt to score goals by passing and dribbling  _RL_ the ball down the field past opposing defenders, and kicking  _RL_ or heading the ball into the goal net, outwitting the defending  _RL_ goalkeeper. Each team consists of  10 outfield players (defenders,  _RL_ midfielders, and strikers) and a goalkeeper. Players from the  _RL_ opposing team may challenge the player in possession of  the ball,  _RL_ but an illegal or foul tackle results in a penalty if  a foul occurs  _RL_ inside the penalty area or a free kick if  outside the penalty area.  _RL_ The round ball used in soccer is more easily controlled than  _RL_ the oval balls used in American, Canadian, and Australian rules  _RL_ football and in rugby. The result is a more “open” or flowing game  _RL_ that is played and watched by millions of  people worldwide. _RL_

IN AMERICAN AND CANADIAN FOOTBALL, the object of the game  _RL_ is to get the ball across the opponent’s goal line, either by passing  _RL_ or carrying it across (a touchdown), or by kicking it between their  _RL_ goalposts (a field goal). An American football team has 11 players  _RL_ on the field at a time, although up to 40 players can appear for each  _RL_ side in a single game. The agile “offense” tries to score points, and  _RL_ the heavy hitting “defense” holds back the opposition. When in  _RL_ possession of  the ball, a team has four chances (“downs”), to move it  _RL_ at least ten yards (nine meters) up the field to make a “first down.”  _RL_ The opposition gains possession if  they fail, or by tackling and  _RL_ intercepting the ball. Canadian football is played on a larger field,  _RL_ with 12 men on each side. A team has only three chances to  _RL_ achieve a first down. Otherwise, the game is very similar  _RL_ to American football. Helmets, face masks, and layers  _RL_ of body padding are worn by the players for protection. _RL_

VARIETIES OF FOOTBALL have developed all over the world and Australian  _RL_ rules football is considered to be one of  the roughest versions, allowing full  _RL_ body tackles even though participants wear no protective padding. The game  _RL_ is played on a large, oval field by two sides, each of  18 players. Players can   _RL_ kick or punch the ball, which is shaped like a rugby ball, but cannot throw  _RL_ it. Running with the ball is permitted, as long as the ball touches the ground  _RL_ at least once every 10 meters. The fullbacks defend two sets of  posts. Teams   _RL_ try to score “goals” (six points) between the inner posts or “behinds” (one  _RL_ point) inside the outer posts. Each game has four quarters of  25 minutes,   _RL_ and the team with the most points at the end of  the allotted time is the  _RL_ winner. In Gaelic football, an Irish version of  soccer (see pp. 524–525), a   _RL_ size 5 soccer ball is used. Each team can have 15 players on the field at a time.  _RL_ Players are allowed to catch, fist, and kick the ball, or dribble it using their  _RL_ hands or feet, but cannot throw it. Teams are awarded three points for getting  _RL_ the ball into the net, and one point for getting it through the posts above the  _RL_ crossbar. Gaelic football is rarely played outside of  Ireland. _RL_

BASKETBALL IS A BALL GAME for two teams of  five players, originally devised  _RL_ in 1890 by James Naismath for the Y.M.C.A. in Springfield, Massachusetts. The  _RL_ object of  the game is to take possession of  the ball and score points by throwing the  _RL_ ball into the opposing team’s basket. A player moves the ball up and down the court  _RL_ by bouncing it along the ground or “dribbling”; the ball may be passed between  _RL_ players by throwing, bouncing, or rolling. Players may not run with or kick the ball,  _RL_ although pivoting on one foot is allowed. The game begins with the referee throwing  _RL_ the ball into the air and a player from each team jumping up to try and “tip” the  _RL_ ball to a teammate. The length of  the game and the number of  periods played varies  _RL_ at different levels. There are amateur, professional, and international rules. No game  _RL_ ends in a draw. An extra period of  five minutes is played, plus as many extra periods  _RL_ as are necessary to break the tie. In addition to the five players on court, each team  _RL_ has up to seven substitutes, but players may only leave the court with the permission  _RL_ of  the referee. Basketball is a noncontact sport and fouls on other players are  _RL_ penalized by a throw-in awarded against the offending team; a free throw at the  _RL_ basket is awarded when a player is fouled in the act of  shooting. Basketball is a  _RL_ fast-moving game, requiring both physical and mental coordination. Skillful tactical  _RL_ play matters more than simple physical strength and the agility of  the players makes  _RL_ the game an excellent spectator sport. _RL_

The first team to score 15 points, with a  _RL_ two- point margin over their opponent, wins the game. Netball is one of  _RL_ the few sports played exclusively by women. Similar to basketball (see   _RL_ pp. 532–533), it is played on a slightly larger court with seven players  _RL_ instead of  five. A team moves the ball toward the goal by throwing,  _RL_ passing, and catching it with the aim of  throwing the ball through the  _RL_ opponents’ goal net. Players are confined by their playing position to  _RL_ specific areas of  the court. Team handball is one of  the world’s fastest  _RL_ games. Each side has seven players. Each team tries  _RL_ to score goals by directing the ball past  _RL_ the opposition’s goalkeeper into the net,  _RL_ which is similar to a soccer net. _RL_

BASEBALL IS A BALL GAME for two teams of  nine players.  _RL_ The batter hits the ball thrown by the opposing team’s pitcher,  _RL_ into the area between the foul lines. He then runs around all four  _RL_ fixed bases in order to score a run, touching or “tagging” each base  _RL_ in turn. The pitcher must throw the ball at a height between the  _RL_ batter’s armpits and knees, a height which is called the “strike  _RL_ zone.” A ball pitched in this area that crosses over the “home plate”  _RL_ is called a “strike” and the batter has three strikes in which to try  _RL_ and hit the ball (otherwise he is “struck out”). The fielding team  _RL_ tries to get the batting team out by catching the ball before it  _RL_ bounces, tagging a player of  the batting team with the ball who  _RL_ is running between bases, or by tagging a base before the player  _RL_ has reached it. Members of  the batting team may stop safely at a  _RL_ base as long as it is not occupied by another member of  their team.  _RL_ When the batter runs to first base, his teammate at first base must  _RL_ run on to second—this is called “force play.” A game consists of  _RL_ nine innings and each team will bat once during an inning. When  _RL_ three members of  the batting team are out, the teams swap roles.  _RL_ The team with the greatest number of  runs wins the game. _RL_

The object  _RL_ of  the game is to score as many runs as possible. Runs can be scored individually by  _RL_ running the length of  the playing strip, or by hitting a ball that lands outside the  _RL_ boundary (“six”), or that lands inside the boundary but bounces or rolls outside   _RL_ (“four”); the opposing team will bowl and field, attempting to dismiss the batsmen.  _RL_ A batsman can be dismissed in one of  several ways: by the bowler hitting the wicket  _RL_ with the ball (“bowled”); by a fielder catching the ball hit by the batsman before  _RL_ it touches the ground (“caught”); by the wicket-keeper or another fielder  _RL_ breaking the wicket while the batsman is attempting a run and is therefore  _RL_ out of  his ground (“stumped” or “run out”); by the batsman breaking  _RL_ the wicket with his own bat or body (“hit wicket”); by a part of  _RL_ the batsman’s body being hit by a ball that would otherwise  _RL_ have hit the wicket (“leg before wicket” [“lbw”]). A match  _RL_ consists of  one or two innings and each inning ends when   _RL_ the tenth batsman of  the batting team is out, when a certain  _RL_ number of  overs (a series of  six balls bowled) have been  _RL_ played, or when the captain of  the batting team  _RL_ “declares” ending the innings voluntarily. _RL_

THE OBJECT OF ALL RACKET SPORTS is to make shots the  _RL_ opponent cannot return. Games are played by two players  _RL_ (singles) or four players (doubles). synthetic, although natural gut is still used. Tennis is played on a court divided   _RL_ by a low net. Opposing players serve alternate games. The first to reach 15 points (11 points for women’s singles) wins the game. Two  _RL_ games are needed to win a match. Squash and racketball are both played in enclosed  _RL_ courts. One player hits the ball against the front wall, and the other tries to return it  _RL_ before it bounces on the floor more than once. Squash rackets have smaller, rounder  _RL_ heads and stiffer frames than badminton rackets. In the United States, the game is played  _RL_ on a narrower court than an international court using a much harder ball. Squash games  _RL_ are played to 15 points (American) or 9 points (international). In racketball, players use a  _RL_ ball that is larger and bouncier than a squash ball. The racket is thick and sturdy, with a  _RL_ large head, short handle, and a thong that loops around the wrist. Points can   _RL_ be won only when serving, and the first player to reach 21 points wins. _RL_

COMBAT SPORTS ARE BASED ON THE SKILLS used in fighting. In these  _RL_ sports, the competitors may be unarmed—as in judo and boxing—or  _RL_ armed—as in fencing and kendo. Judo is a system of  unarmed combat  _RL_ developed in the East. Translated from the Japanese, the name means  _RL_ “the gentle way.” Students learn how to turn an opponent’s force to their  _RL_ own advantage. The usual costume is loose white pants and a jacket,  _RL_ fastened with a cloth belt. The color of  belt indicates the student’s level   _RL_ of  expertise, from white-belted novices to the expert “black belts.”  _RL_ Competitions take place on a mat or “shiaijo,” 30 or 33 ft (9 or 10 m)  _RL_ square in size, bounded by “danger” and “safety” areas to prevent injury.  _RL_ Competitors try to throw, pin, or master their opponent by applying  _RL_ pressure to the arm joints or neck. Competitors try to touch specific  _RL_ target areas on their opponent with their sword or “foil” while avoiding  _RL_ being touched themselves. Three types of  swords are used—foils, épées, and sabers.  _RL_ Official foil and épée competitions always use an electric scoring system.  _RL_ The sword tips are connected to lights by a long wire that passes  _RL_ underneath each fencer’s jacket. ANGLING MEANS FISHING WITH A ROD, reel, line, and lure.  _RL_ There are several different types of  angling: freshwater  _RL_ coarse angling, for members of  the carp family and pike;  _RL_ freshwater game angling, for salmon and trout; and sea  _RL_ angling, for sea fish such as flatfish, bass, and mackerel.  _RL_ Anglers use a variety of  methods for catching fish. These  _RL_ include bait fishing, in which bait (food to allure the fish)  _RL_ is placed on a hook and cast into the water; fly fishing, in  _RL_ which a natural or artificial fly is used to lure the fish;  _RL_ and spinning, in which a lure that looks like a small fish  _RL_ revolves as it is pulled through the water. The angler uses  _RL_ the rod, reel, and line to cast the lure over the water. The  _RL_ reel controls the line as it spills off  the spool and as it is  _RL_ wound back. Weights may be fixed to  _RL_ the line so that it will sink. Swivels  _RL_ are attached to prevent the line  _RL_ from twisting. When a fish bites,  _RL_ the hook must become embedded  _RL_ in its mouth and remain there  _RL_ while the catch is reeled in. _RL_

However, in most other respects  _RL_ PCs and Macs have much in common.  _RL_ Both contain microchips, or integrated circuits,  _RL_ that store and process data. The “brain” of  any  _RL_ PC is a chip known as the central processing  _RL_ unit (CPU), which performs mathematical  _RL_ operations in order to run program  _RL_ instructions and receive, store, and output  _RL_ data. The most powerful personal computer  _RL_ CPUs today can perform more than a  _RL_ billion calculations a second. Data can be  _RL_ input via CDs, USB memory sticks, and  _RL_ other storage media. Highly portable  _RL_ laptop and network PCs are also in  _RL_ widespread use. Most PCs are able   _RL_ to communicate with many other   _RL_ devices, including digital cameras   _RL_ (see pp. 580-81) and smartphones   _RL_ (see pp. 588-89). _RL_

SCANNERS CONVERT physical  _RL_ images into electronic form,  _RL_ allowing them to be sent over the  _RL_ internet, displayed on a website,  _RL_ stored on a computer, and  _RL_ manipulated using specialized  _RL_ software. Scanners work by  _RL_ detecting and analyzing light  _RL_ reflected from an opaque image,  _RL_ such as a photographic print.  _RL_ Some can also scan photographic  _RL_ transparencies by analyzing light  _RL_ that has passed through the image.  _RL_ Flatbed scanners contain a unit,  _RL_ called the scan head, that contains  _RL_ a lamp, mirrors, a lens, and an  _RL_ array of  CCDs (Charge-Coupled  _RL_ Devices). The carriage passes  _RL_ beneath the image; the lamp  _RL_ shines light on to or through the  _RL_ original; the mirrors reflect the  _RL_ light on to the lens, which focuses  _RL_ it on to the CCD array. Each CCD  _RL_ detects the brightness of  light   _RL_ from a particular pixel (picture  _RL_ element) along a· horizontal strip  _RL_ and converts this data into an  _RL_ electric signal. For color images,  _RL_ the light is usually passed through  _RL_ red, green, and blue filters and  _RL_ then directed to the CCD array   _RL_ so that it can be broken down   _RL_ into its component colors. This  _RL_ information is then converted to  _RL_ digital form. The quality of  the  _RL_ image depends on its resolution,  _RL_ measured in dpi (Dots Per Inch). _RL_

INKJET PRINTERS EXPEL ink droplets from hundreds  _RL_ of  tiny jets, or nozzles, on to a medium, such as paper,  _RL_ to print an image. Each droplet corresponds to a  _RL_ single pixel (picture element). Black-and-white  _RL_ printers use only black ink, while color printers  _RL_ overprint combinations of  the printing colors (cyan,  _RL_ yellow, magenta, and black) to create a full color  _RL_ range. The printhead containing the nozzles moves  _RL_ sideways across the paper, creating a line of  pixels,  _RL_ before the paper moves slightly forward so the next  _RL_ line can be printed. Two basic methods are used to  _RL_ eject ink: thermal, in which ink is heated to form an  _RL_ expanding bubble that expels a droplet from the  _RL_ nozzle, and piezoelectric, in which an electric current  _RL_ expands a crystal causing it to push out the ink  _RL_ droplet. VIDEO GAMES HAVE BEEN around  _RL_ since the early 1970s. They are played  _RL_ on PCs, arcade machines, on a TV  _RL_ using a home console, and on  _RL_ portable handheld consoles. Players  _RL_ use devices such as joysticks and  _RL_ control pads with buttons to control  _RL_ movement and action on screen.   _RL_

The latest generation of consoles uses motion sensor technology   _RL_ to allow players to manipulate objects on screen by simply moving  _RL_ the controller. FOR MORE THAN 200 YEARS, CAMERAS recorded  _RL_ pictures as chemical changes in silver-containing  _RL_ substances, on a strip of  flexible, celluloid film.  _RL_ The digital camera records pictures in electronic  _RL_ form. At its heart is a specialized integrated  _RL_ circuit known as a charge-coupled device (CCD).  _RL_ This has millions of  microunits known as pixels.  _RL_ It works in the opposite way from a miniature  _RL_ computer or TV screen. Instead of  electric signals  _RL_ making pixels shine, when light hits a pixel it  _RL_ generates a tiny electrical signal, according to   _RL_ the light’s color and brightness. The signals   _RL_ from the CCD’s millions of  pixels are analogue:  _RL_ they vary continuously in a wavelike fashion.  _RL_ They are converted by a microchip to digital   _RL_ codes of  numbers, represented as on-off  electronic  _RL_ pulses. The digital signals are processed and fed   _RL_ to the camera’s internal memory or a removable  _RL_ memory device such as a data card or memory  _RL_ stick. Photographs can be downloaded from a  _RL_ digital camera to a computer via a cable or in  _RL_ some cases a wireless link. Some digital cameras  _RL_ automatically reduce blurring caused by camera  _RL_ shake or fast movement, some can record video  _RL_ clips as well as still pictures. _RL_

Digital  _RL_ video cameras convert the signal into digital  _RL_ form—a series of separate measurements   _RL_ of the initial analogue (continuously varying)  _RL_ signal. They record the digital signal, usually on  _RL_ a chip or hard disk. Video cameras often have   _RL_ a slot where a memory card can be inserted   _RL_ to expand the memory and store longer  _RL_ recordings or more still pictures. _RL_

HOME CINEMA REPLICATES a real “movie theater” using  _RL_ pictures displayed on a high-quality widescreen television set,  _RL_ such as a plasma TV, and surround sound from strategically  _RL_ sited loudspeakers. The source for sound and vision is a DVD  _RL_ (Digital Versatile Disc). Its player uses standard CD (Compact  _RL_ Disc) digital technology, but with a higher density of  laser- _RL_ read microscopic pits—more than 20 billion such pits in  _RL_ multilevel spiral tracks that, stretched out, would extend  _RL_ nearly 25 miles (40km). Blu-ray is a high-quality DVD system  _RL_ that fits much more data on its disc than standard DVDs,  _RL_ allowing High Definition video files to be stored. It is hard   _RL_ for the human ear to discern the direction of  low-pitched  _RL_ sounds, so these emanate from a central bass  _RL_ speaker, often built into or below the screen unit.  _RL_ High-pitched sounds, the direction of  which is  _RL_ easier to detect, emanate from mid- and high- _RL_ frequency speakers positioned around the viewer.  _RL_ Plasma screens use fluorescent tube (“strip- _RL_ light”) technology. Tiny three-cell pixels, each  _RL_ about one millimeter across, contain red, green,  _RL_ and blue phosphor chemicals and a gas mix.  _RL_ Where electric pulses coincide for a split second  _RL_ in the crisscross matrix of  wire electrodes, the  _RL_ gas energizes and emits ultraviolet light, which  _RL_ in turn makes the phosphor glow. _RL_

Cellphones have also  _RL_ generally shrunk in size, due to improvements   _RL_ in rechargeable batteries, which now store more  _RL_ electricity for longer in a smaller package, and   _RL_ to smaller, more efficient electronics that use less  _RL_ electricity. THE GLOBAL POSITIONING SYSTEM (GPS) is a network of  _RL_ 24 navigation satellites orbiting the Earth that people can   _RL_ use to pinpoint their position. The satellites orbit at a height   _RL_ of 12,500 miles (20,000 km). A GPS receiver picks up signals   _RL_ from any of these satellites that are above the horizon. It can calculate its position on the Earth’s surface   _RL_ when it has information from at least three satellites. A basic   _RL_ GPS receiver shows the latitude and longitude   _RL_ of its position on its screen. More advanced  _RL_ receivers, especially those designed for use   _RL_ in vehicles, show their position on a digital  _RL_ map. These receivers often show extra  _RL_ information, such as the vehicle’s speed and  _RL_ the length of the journey. Some receivers  _RL_ warn drivers if they exceed the speed limit  _RL_ for a road and even tell drivers which  _RL_ traffic lane to use at the next junction.  _RL_ Directions are shown on the screen and  _RL_ also spoken by a synthesized voice. _RL_

IN A CONVENTIONAL VACUUM CLEANER, an electric motor  _RL_ spins a fan that sucks in air carrying dust and debris. The air  _RL_ is forced through tiny pores in a dust bag, trapping most  _RL_ particles. In the 1990s, James Dyson’s dual cyclone “bagless”  _RL_ design did away with the dust bag—and the reduced airflow  _RL_ caused by clogging of  its pores. An electrically driven fan  _RL_ creates a partial vacuum within the machine. This sucks air  _RL_ into the machine past a rotating brush that loosens dirt. The  _RL_ air flows into a cylinder-shaped bin. As the air whirls around  _RL_ the bin like a miniature storm, or cyclone, larger particle  _RL_ are flung outward and fall to the bottom of  the bin. The  _RL_ air then passes through perforations into a cone-shaped  _RL_ inner bin and then into a series of  smaller cones, spinning  _RL_ faster all the time and flinging smaller and smaller particle  _RL_ out. The nearly clean air exits the  _RL_ machine through microfilters that  _RL_ trap the tiniest particles. Some  _RL_ Dyson vacuum cleaners run on   _RL_ a large ball instead of  wheels.   _RL_ The ball makes it easier to   _RL_ steer the cleaner. _RL_

Machines with electric heaters and motors  _RL_ took the strain out of  washing from the 1910s. Up to the 1960s, three  _RL_ machines were needed to wash, spin, and dry. Now clothes are  _RL_ swirled in a rotating ribbed tub of  hot water, then spun fast to throw  _RL_ off  most of  the water, before slowly tumbling in electrically heated  _RL_ air to dry—all in one appliance. _RL_

But they do pass  _RL_ through most types of  plastic, ceramics, and  _RL_ glass. Therefore platters or containers made  _RL_ from these materials are suitable for use in  _RL_ microwave ovens. MOST ELECTRIC TOASTERS not only grill slices of  bread, but  _RL_ they also pop them up when ready. While the slices rest on a  _RL_ spring-loaded rack, electric heating elements toast the bread.   _RL_ At the same time, a bimetallic strip heats and  _RL_ expands. One of  the two metals in this strip  _RL_ expands more quickly than the other, causing  _RL_ the strip to curve. As it bends, it completes  _RL_ an electrical circuit and activates an  _RL_ electromagnet. The magnet attracts a  _RL_ catch, releasing the spring that holds  _RL_ the rack down in the toaster. The  _RL_ elements switch off, and the  _RL_ toasted slices pop up. _RL_

THE ELECTRICALLY POWERED MOTOR OF A POWER DRILL, cooled by a fan, turns a  _RL_ shaft at high speed. The shaft connects, in turn, to a system of  gears that rotates  _RL_ a chuck even faster. Clamped by the chuck, a sharp bit cuts out the hole, and  _RL_ at the same time the bit’s screw-shaped grooves channel the waste out of  _RL_ the hole. For drilling hard materials, many power drills have  _RL_ a hammer mechanism; when this is operated a ratchet in  _RL_ the gearcase causes the chuck and bit to pound in and  _RL_ out as they drill. A hand drill, although slower and  _RL_ less forceful than a power drill, is easier to control.  _RL_ For cutting wide holes, carpenters often prefer a  _RL_ brace-and-bit. This acts like a lever: the bowed  _RL_ handle of  the brace moves a larger  _RL_ distance than the bit, turning the bit  _RL_ with extra force.  _RL_

HOUSES IN THE FUTURE are likely  _RL_ to be more environmentally friendly  _RL_ and energy-efficient than older  _RL_ dwellings, by making better use  _RL_ of materials and intelligent control  _RL_ systems. Extensive use is made  _RL_ of recycled, natural, and renewable  _RL_ materials and energy. The walls are  _RL_ made from timber and insulated with  _RL_ fiber from recycled newspaper; waste  _RL_ water from the bathrooms is saved  _RL_ and used to flush the toilets; and  _RL_ a wind turbine and solar panels  _RL_ contribute some of  the electricity  _RL_ requirements. Many elements were  _RL_ prefabricated off-site for ease of  _RL_ construction. The Integer house uses  _RL_ only half  the energy and a third less  _RL_ water than a traditionally built house. _RL_

RENEWABLE ENERGY COMES from sources that  _RL_ do not become depleted as we use the energy.  _RL_ When a fossil fuel such as coal is burned, it is  _RL_ gone forever, but a renewable source remains  _RL_ available no matter how much is used. The  _RL_ tides, waves, flowing water, sunlight, and the  _RL_ wind are all renewable sources of  energy.  _RL_ Wind and water energy are captured by a  _RL_ device called a turbine. The turbine spins and  _RL_ drives an electricity generator. Energy from  _RL_ sunlight, or solar energy, is changed into  _RL_ electricity in two main ways. One uses  _RL_ mirrors to concentrate solar energy and  _RL_ magnify its heating effect which is used to  _RL_ change water into steam to drive turbines.  _RL_ Photovoltaic cells change sunlight directly  _RL_ into electricity. A cell is made from two layers  _RL_ of  silicon. One gives out electrons (negative  _RL_ particles) and the other receives them.  _RL_ Sunlight knocks electrons out of atoms where  _RL_ the two layers meet, separating them from  _RL_ the positive particles. The electrons are  _RL_ attracted to one layer of  the cell, the positive  _RL_ particles to the other layer. Electrons are  _RL_ naturally attracted to the positive particles,  _RL_ but to come together again, the electrons  _RL_ must flow out of  the cell, through an external  _RL_ electric circuit, or load, and back to the other  _RL_ side of  the cell, creating a charge. The cell  _RL_ supplies electric current for as long as light  _RL_ keeps falling on it. _RL_

IN A LIVING CELL THE GENETIC MATERIAL DNA (deoxyribonucleic  _RL_ acid) contains thousands of  units called genes that carry  _RL_ instructions for development, growth, and repair of  the living  _RL_ creature. During normal reproduction, half  the mother’s genetic  _RL_ material contained in an egg cell joins with half  the genetic  _RL_ material from the father carried in a sperm cell, to form a  _RL_ unique new genome (set of  genes) for a new life. During the  _RL_ early stages of  embryo development, the fertilized egg divides  _RL_ into stem cells, which have the potential to become  _RL_ specialized into the hundreds of  cell types in a  _RL_ body. Through therapeutic cloning, stem cells  _RL_ can be produced in a laboratory. It is hoped that  _RL_ in the future this technology can be used to grow  _RL_ new tissue that can be transplanted back into the  _RL_ donor to treat illness, without fear of  rejection— _RL_ when the body recognizes a transplanted part  _RL_ as “foreign” because it has different genes, and  _RL_ tries to destroy it. ROBOTS ARE  _RL_ MACHINES THAT CAN  _RL_ carry out a variety of  _RL_ tasks on their own,  _RL_ with little or no human  _RL_ control. OPTICAL MICROSCOPES FORM A MAGNIFIED image by using  _RL_ lenses to bend light. Time advances  _RL_ by one hour for every 15° longitude east of  _RL_ Greenwich (and goes back one hour for  _RL_ every 15° west), but the system is adjusted  _RL_ in line with administrative boundaries.  _RL_ Numbers on the map indicate the number  _RL_ of hours that must be added to, or  _RL_ subtracted from UTC to calculate the time  _RL_ in each zone. Thus, the eastern United  _RL_ States (–5) is 5 hours behind UTC. _RL_

JEWISH _RL_ The Jewish calendar is a lunar calendar  _RL_ adapted to the solar year. It normally has 12  _RL_ months but in leap years, which occur seven  _RL_ times in every cycle of  19 years, there are 13  _RL_ months. CHINESE _RL_ The Chinese calendar is a lunar calendar,  _RL_ with a year consisting of  12 months.  _RL_ Intercalary months are added to keep the  _RL_ calendar in step with the solar year of  365  _RL_ days. Months are referred to by a number  _RL_ within a year, but also by animal names  _RL_ that, from ancient times, have been  _RL_ attached to years and hours of  the day. _RL_
